results.headline: Young Girl Grapples With the Facts of Life
results.summary_short: In “Tiger Eyes,” the film version of Judy Blume’s young-adult novel, directed by her son, Lawrence Blume, a teenage girl deals with death, dislocation and sexual awakening.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tiger Eyes

results.headline: A Long, Strange Trip Back Home
results.summary_short: “The Rambler” follows a drifter hitchhiking from the Southwest to his brother’s ranch in Oregon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Rambler

results.headline: A Night When No Bad Deed Goes Punished
results.summary_short: In “The Purge,” with Ethan Hawke and Lena Headey, an America of the future allows crime with impunity once a year.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Purge

results.headline: A Criminal to Root For
results.summary_short: In “The Prey,” a bank robber escapes from prison to defend his family and his stash from a serial killer, and leads the police on quite a chase.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La proie

results.headline: Laurel and Hardy in Google’s Toyland
results.summary_short: In “The Internship,” set in a mock-up of Google’s headquarters, Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson play analog guys thrust into a digital world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Internship

results.headline: Barred From Heaven, and Now the Devil Wants a Date
results.summary_short: “Rapture-Palooza,” a comedy directed by Paul Middleditch, depicts the travails of people left behind in suburban Seattle after the Rapture arrives and takes the faithful to heaven.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rapture-Paloooza

results.headline: Heady Times in Exotic Iceland
results.summary_short: Andrea Sisson and Pete Ohs feature Iceland’s natural wonders and Ms. Sisson’s philosophical ruminations in “I Send You This Place.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Send You This Place

results.headline: A Toast to the Stars of Mixology
results.summary_short: “Hey Bartender” is Douglas Tirola’s documentary ode to high-end mixologists.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hey Bartender

results.headline: So Many Culprits in a Teenage Rampage
results.summary_short: “Hello Herman,” adapted from John Buffalo Mailer’s 2001 play, depicts a bullied 16-year-old who slaughters dozens of classmates and several adults.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hello Herman

results.headline: Epiphanies on the Ice Cream Truck Route
results.summary_short: In “Free Samples,” directed by Jay Gammill, a law school dropout takes over her friend’s ice cream truck for a day and encounters some revelatory characters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free Samples

results.headline: A Repressed Sect’s Ordeal, via Two Victims
results.summary_short: “Free China: The Courage to Believe,” directed by Michael Perlman, is a work of advocacy, calling attention to the persecution of the Falun Gong sect in China.
results.display_title: Free China: The Courage to Believe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free China: The Courage to Believe

results.headline: Failed Writer Entangled in Domestic Dramas
results.summary_short: A failed writer moves back in with his wacky family in Carlo De Rosa’s “Finding Joy.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Finding Joy

results.headline: Hopes Pinned on a Daughter Wise Beyond Her Years
results.summary_short: In “As Cool as I Am,” Claire Danes plays an unhappily married woman with a feisty daughter.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As Cool As I Am

results.headline: Deadly Ice and Wild Dogs, but Oh, the Vistas
results.summary_short: “1 Mile Above,” a drama directed by Du Jiayi, depicts a young Taiwanese man who vows to complete an arduous bicycle trek to Tibet on behalf of his brother, who died en route.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Mile Above

results.headline: Fate of the Earth Rests on a Banjo
results.summary_short: In “The History of Future Folk,” music-loving space aliens are on a mission to invade Earth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The History of Future Folk

results.headline: Watch Your Back, Even in the Family
results.summary_short: Politics, secret agents and strained family relations are part of “Shadow Dancer,” a thriller set in Britain.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shadow Dancer

results.headline: Retired in America, Reborn in Guatemala
results.summary_short: The documentary “La Camioneta” follows the journey of a decommissioned American school bus as it travels from Virginia to Guatemala.
results.display_title: La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Camioneta: The Journey of One American School Bus

results.headline: Warning: Woman Wields a Scalpel
results.summary_short: The scalpel takes center stage in this horror film from the Soska sisters about appearances and their manipulation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Mary

results.headline: Trapped by an Invisible Force
results.summary_short: A woman vacationing in the Austrian mountains finds herself cut off from the world by a transparent barrier in “The Wall.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wall

results.headline: Into the Hormonal Wild
results.summary_short: “The Kings of Summer,” directed by Jordan Vogt-Roberts, centers on three teenage boys who run away from home — but not very far — and live out a comic wilderness fantasy.
